meanings.definition: Give (someone) the authority or power to do something.
meanings.sent1: The teacher will empower the students to choose their own project topics.
meanings.sent2: The new law will empower citizens to vote in the upcoming election.
meanings.sent3: The magic wand empowered the young wizard to cast powerful spells.
meanings.sent4: The key to success is to empower yourself with knowledge and determination.
meanings.sent5: The superhero's cape seemed to empower him with incredible strength and speed.

meanings.definition: Make (someone) stronger and more confident, especially in controlling their life and claiming their rights.
meanings.sent1: Learning new skills can empower individuals to pursue their dreams.
meanings.sent2: The supportive community empowered her to speak up for what she believed in.
meanings.sent3: The talking parrot empowered the pirate to have amusing conversations at sea.
meanings.sent4: The wise advice from her grandmother empowered her to face life's challenges bravely.
meanings.sent5: The rising sun seemed to empower the flowers to bloom brightly in the garden.
